fear.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the feeling you get when you are afraid or worried that something bad is going to happen
fear.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: There are fears that share prices could decrease still further.
The girl’s parents expressed fears for her safety.
The children looked at her in fear.
People must be able to express their views without fear of criticism.
fear.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the possibility or danger that something bad might happen
fear.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: There’s no fear of revolt now.
fear.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: somebody’s worst/greatest fear
Her worst fear was never seeing her children again.
an irrational fear
He grew up with an irrational fear of insects.
a deep-seated fear
He exploited people’s deep-seated fears about strangers.
groundless
As it turned out, these fears were groundless.
conquer/overcome your fear
She managed to conquer her fear of flying.
shake/tremble with fear
He was shaking with fear after being held at gunpoint.
show fear
She was determined not to show fear.
be gripped by fear
We were gripped by fear as the boat was tossed around by the waves.
be paralysed with fear
Bruce was paralysed with fear when he saw the snake.
confirm somebody’s fears
The look on Colin’s face confirmed all my worst fears.
ease/allay/dispel somebody’s fears
Frank eased my fears about not being able to speak the local language.
be in fear of/for your life
Celia was in fear of her life when she saw the truck coming toward her.
be full of fear
The residents are too full of fear to leave their houses.
be/live in fear of something
They were constantly in fear of an enemy attack.
have no fear of something
He had no fear of death.
somebody’s hopes and fears
We each had different hopes and fears about the trip.
fear.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: fear
a feeling of being frightened
He was trembling with fear.
Fear of failure should not stop you trying.
terror
a feeling of great fear, because you think that something terrible is about to happen
She let out a scream of pure terror.
fright
a sudden feeling of fear, or a situation that makes you feel this
My body was shaking with fright.
You gave me a fright!
He’s had a bit of fright, that’s all.
panic
a sudden feeling of fear or nervousness that makes you unable to think clearly or behave sensibly
She was in such a panic that she hardly knew what she was doing!
There were scenes of sheer panic immediately following the bomb blast.
alarm
a feeling of fear or worry which shows in your voice or behaviour, because you think something bad might happen
When I mentioned her name, he looked up at me in alarm.
The streets were calm and there was no sign of alarm.
foreboding
a feeling that something bad or unpleasant might happen although there is no obvious reason why it should
She felt the same sense of foreboding she had before her father died.
phobia
a permanent strong unreasonable fear of something
I had a phobia about going to the dentist.
fear.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to feel afraid or worried that something bad may happen
fear.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Fearing violence, the group asked for police protection.
Hundreds of people are feared dead in the ferry disaster.
a terrifying ordeal in which she feared for her life
Police fear that there may be further terrorist attacks.
Women feared to go out at night.
His wife seemed depressed, and he feared for his children.
fear.translation[1].definitions[0].note_: In more formal English, you say it is feared that something is true
It is feared that the child has been abducted
fear.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to be afraid of someone and what they might do
fear.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: As a leader, he was distrusted and even feared.
